column1: Between 12 August 2019 and 30 November 2019, will Russia and Iran conduct any joint naval exercises in the Strait of Hormuz?
column6: ['Security and Conflict']
maintaining forecast

Time's about up
Little time left.

Between 12 August 2019 and 30 November 2019, will Russia and Iran conduct any joint naval exercises in the Strait of Hormuz? Late to this party.
Unlikely at the moment.
It's increasingly looking like the comments made towards this eventuality was just more bellicose rhetoric and saber rattling.
-20%. Not much news on this recently and time is short.
civil unrest in Iran and preoccupation of the US administration make it increasingly unlikely that either side will escalate in the near term.
-12%, time decay
Updating for the time left: I originally estimated a 6% for two months, now there are 2/3 of a month left.
Dropping to zero because there isn't much time left.

I'm not aware of any announcement, much less the planning needed for a true joint exercise in the Indian Ocean/Gulf of Oman Like I wrote back in August - they could do joint-exercise-lite by re-flagging a couple of Iranian attack boats, man them with Russian crews, and call that a joint exercise. So I keep a 1% chance of "something" happening before month end.
-13%. Time decay.

There has been no announcement of a joint exercise that will take place in Nov. A joint exercise would need significant advertisement and coordination to ensure the exercise does not escalate into a conflict. Additionally, with Turkey invading Syria, Russia is tied up at the moment with the military and political ramifications of Turkey's actions. Mr. Trump is tied up in impeachment tweets and doesn't have time to continue to poke and provoke Iran into wanting to hold the exercises. China has not indicated it wants to hurry any naval exercises along which could show they only tentatively support the exercises. Too many obstacles to overcome in the next 26 days to hold a joint exercise. Hardly likely to occur in 2019 at all.

With one month left before the close of this time window and current high tensions in the region, it seems unlikely that Russo-Iranian military cooperation will manifest in overt naval exercises in the Strait of Hormuz by 30 November. However, there are numerous signs that point to probable future cooperation in the maritime space. Many have already raised an MOU signed July 2019 between the Russian Federation and Iranian Navies - which seems to suggest at least the plausibility of joint Russian-Iranian naval exercises. Given the nature of the Iranian fleet as a littoral defense force and Russia's increased demonstrations of their 'blue water' capabilities, it seems very likely Russian naval presence in the region will grow (a number of Russian warships have transversed the Suez canal in the past three years for stated anti-piracy reasons among other things)
Still unlikely, it would be rushed if it did occur
Trump is signaling that there no consequences for Turkey. Other countries to follow.
Lowering probability since the development situation in Syria
Too brazen
Russia is focused on Turkey / Syria. Russia would like to be seen as peacemakers / kingmakers in the region

Joint military exercise is not planned in the Strait of Hormuz, rather in Sea of Oman or Indian Ocean.

There has been no inter-country naval drills in the strait of Hormuz in the recent past. As a strategically important strait, conducting a naval drill here will send the wrong signal all around the world. The move will be seen as too provocative/aggressive.
absence of any information . . . Wouldn't the purpose of such an exercise be to impress other countries? So wouldn't they want a lot of PR? Yet, there is nothing.
no significant change in outlook.

Second hand reporting of a Tasnim news agency release says a joint naval drill with Russia and China is being planned for the Gulf of Oman and the northern part of the Indian Ocean. No timeline was released. There was a specific negation of any intention to hold these drills in the Persian Gulf. However, when I went to the Tasmin site - no such story came up. Nevertheless, Gulf of Oman is not the Strait of Hormuz. So reduce the likelihood of this possibility still further.
passage of time

Russia, Iran, and China’s power come from the threat of action, or intimidation of smaller and larger countries. See “mother in law” power as defined by political theorist Hans Morgenthau.

Going lower because planning exercises takes time and I haven't seen the evidence that Russia in particular is rushing to do this.
Cannot see Russia making such a strategic mistake. Information seems to be coming only from Iran side. If Russia was making this type of commitment -maybe, but no can not see it this year.

It was announces in July with no follow ups from either side since then. The news seems to come from Iran side only and I did no see confirmation from Russian side anywhere. There was no dates/years mentioned. Earlier this year Iran also announces naval exercises in Caspian Sea, which have not happened yet either.
Possible but not much likely to occur.
Economically, these countries can't afford an impressive naval exercise.
Reading the comments from @Anneinak and a previous analysis from @Kitsonj, I am inclined to reduce the probability a bit further, from 9% to 6%, a factor of 2/3 of my previous probability.

This seems less likely to happen at all than it did in August, and recent accounts also mention doing the exercises in the Gulf of Oman instead of the Straight of Hormuz, lowering the probability even further.

I have reduced the probability from 22 to 9%. Reasons: (i) the previous 22% was an average between a log-normal distribution (6 months average, "log(6-4)" variance) and a constant probability in time from here to the Iranian new year, yielding a 33%, (ii) if we notice that if we assume that the total probability of exercises from here till the Iranian new year is not necessarily a 100%, but maybe a 50%, the previous 33% will transform into a 16.5%, coinciding with the log-normal distribution, which means that my previous 22% anchor was too high, (iii) the Chinese apparently have some interest to joint, according to the Iranians, though China-based military analyst doubt that the involvement will be serious (might be limited to anti-piracy operations), (iv) the involvement of the Chinese might, if anything, complicate the coordination, (v) right now, after the attack to Saudi Arabia, probably there is no a great interest to hold the maritime exercises soon. Instead it will better to wait till things have calmed down and then throw the media-bomb of the joint naval exercises.
The US is still weak vs Russia and Putin so I can see them getting this done before he gets voted out.
No benefit for Russia at this time.

Russia will continue to want to engage with its allies in the Middle East however not at the cost of intervention from the US. Especially given recent oil attacks on Saudi Arabia. Statements made that Iran will have exercises in the the Gulf of oman have been made, whether they will go through the strait of Hormuz and before the 30th of November

With US's declining hegemony in Middle East, don't think Russia want to jeopardize its chances of expanding its relationship with middle east. Nothing to win in Russia's case, even china's so called military drills with iran and russia are largely reduced to outside activites such as anti piracy, not willing to risk China's relationship with the middle east, due to its heavy reliance on oil. Russia is heavily reliant on middle east for the expansion of its exports and development of nuclear power. Russia's relationship with Iran's adversaries have all been rather good in the last 6 months or so.

In recent weeks it feels more like a squeeze and tease mentality at play - cat and mouse. Unless something drastic happens that encourages any of the major players to make a strike, then I don't see such naval exercises taking place in the near future.

Conflicting accounts and possible walk-backs by Iranian State news (https://www.newsweek.com/russia-iran-train-fight-back-us-1452689) made it seem like even odds the exercises even happened before next March (2020). Given the drone strikes on Saudi Oil, it is unlikely that the exercises will occur at all based on increasing tensions in the region. China will most likely not participate in exercises in the Persian Gulf because they have already walked back their involvement (https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3030032/china-expected-send-anti-piracy-fleet-not-navy-joint-drill) and it seems as if Russia and Iran would not want to lose the support of China in joint exercises specifically in the Gulf.

Approach: 1. Context of the question: "Earlier this week, Rear Admiral of the Iranian Navy Hossein Khanzadi confirmed prior reports that Tehran and Moscow have signed an agreement to hold joint Naval drills: "Earlier, we signed an agreement [on joint exercises] with Russia’s Armed Forces and the Russian Fleet’s command. Soon the preparations and maneuvers’ planning will start and they will be carried out this year.” 06/08/2019 From <https://nationalinterest.org/blog/buzz/iran-and-russia-getting-ready-hold-joint-naval-drills-strait-hormuz-71661> Note that this is only a memorandum, with no binding character. 2. History: have both countries ever conducted joint ops? Or combined ops? With what countries do they practice combined operations? • In 2015, there was a joint naval ops in Azerbaijan. Iran lent their ships to a Russian exercise (+) https://tinyurl.com/y2jp6sqr Flotilla was very small, consisting of a destroyer and 2 missile carriers. • Last naval joint operation was in 2017 in the Caspian Sea. Recent time, both national leaders still in office (+). Large flottilla with marine participation https://www.mei.edu/publications/irans-navy-launches-five-day-naval-drills-caspian-sea • Russia is scaling operations with non-Nato countries (+) https://www.cnbc.com/2019/09/17/russia-conducts-tsentr-2019-military-exercises-with-china-and-india.html, including in the same drill space as Nato https://tinyurl.com/y62vwnrc. However, no operations were made outside their immediate influence zone (~) 3. What classifies as a naval combined operation? How many ships? Apparently sending as little as 3 ships to Azerbaijan classifies as a joint naval operation. Any participation of Russian personnel in Iranian drills or vice versa will be classified as such. 4. Why would they do it? How do both countries project their power? • Russia has not made any ops or drills in contested territory outside of their immediate proximity. That might change eventually of course. Iran has been capturing tankers in Hormuz. • Given the context of the capture of the oil tankers, a joint exercise in hormuz would not be scandalous (+) 5. What is the general geo-political situation? US-Iran It is my impression that Trump is currently easing out from the middle east and focusing on China (broadly speaking). The withdrawal from Syria and his position relating to the events after the houthi attack on the Saudi refining facilities suggests this is a main trait of the Trump administration. Russia-Middle East • Apart from some logistical and ground support, Russia is not interacting with the middle eastern front remotely as much as the media would have most people believe. For example, the S300 system sold to Syria is yet to be delivered, despite dire need of said system by their syrian "allies". This is probably to avoid interfering with Israeli interests. Russia has no interest in creating a conflict with Saudi Arabia -quite the contrary, as they would make an excelent weapons client for the russian military complex, and an convenient ally in future oil disruptions. Russia-Saudi Arabia  During 2017, Saudi Arabia encouraged the United States to remove sanctions on Russia pertaining to its activity in Ukraine in exchange for Russian assistance in ending the Iranian military presence in Syria.[48]  Russia has remained neutral between Saudi Arabia and Qatar in the 2017–18 Qatar diplomatic crisis, offering to mediate in July 2017.[49]  In December 2017, Russia withdrew diplomatic representation from the Houthi-held Yemeni capital Sana'a, in opposition to the killing of former Yemeni President Ali Abdullah Saleh by the Houthis. The killing took place as a consequence of his defection from the Houthi-dominated Supreme Political Council to the Saudi coalition in the Yemeni Civil War.[50]  From December 2017 onward, Saudi Arabia abandoned its past support for UN resolutions condemning the Russian military intervention in Ukraine, instead choosing to abstain.[51][52] In August 2018, Russia backed Saudi Arabia in its dispute with Canada, with Russian foreign ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova stating that "the politicization of human rights matters is unacceptable".[53]  In the aftermath of the assassination of Jamal Khashoggi in October 2018, Putin stated that Russia "cannot start deteriorating relations" with Saudi Arabia as "it did not know what really happened."[54] His press secretary, Dmitry Peskov, later added that there was "no reason basically not to believe" the official statements issued by Saudi Arabia on the matter.[55] In December 2018, Russian deputy foreign minister Mikhail Bogdanov warned the United States against interference in the line of succession to the Saudi throne by pushing for the ouster of Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman, following reports that U.S. officials would support replacing him with Ahmed bin Abdulaziz.[56] Bogdanov stated that "the King made a decision and I can’t even imagine on what grounds someone in America will interfere in such an issue and think about who should rule Saudi Arabia, now or in the future."[57] From <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_relations#Saudi_King's_visit_to_Russia_(October_2017)> Forecast: No action. Given the context of Russian positive involvement with Saudi Arabia and Trump's desire to cool the middle eastern front, it is likely that operations that might trigger a strong-arm reaction from Trump will not be attempted. 20/09/2019

The United States has imposed sanctions on Iran's central bank, US President Donald Trump says at the White House, nearly a week after attacks on oil facilities in Saudi Arabia that some US officials have pinned on Tehran. Friday, September 20

With only 10 weeks to go until 30 November, and the current drama in the Gulf, it seems very unlikely that Russia would be in any rush to provoke Saudi Arabia, Israel or the US by doing military exercises in such a strategic location.

Well, it's difficult to make a prediction. Naval exercises can happen really fast after announcement or might happen really late. There were announcements of joint exercises in the Caspian sea around January, which did not materialize yet and which are in principle unrelated to the Strait of Hormuz, but which might give a clue with regards to the expected delay. For the strait of Hormuz in June it was hope to happen in the following months or before the end of the Persian new year (March 20, 2020), not clear which one of the two. Now apparently the Russian navy will arrive for the end of the year. According to one source in some of the multiple news I was checking, Iran likes to hold naval exercises in autumn, but in 2019 they happen in February, in 2018 in August and in 2017 in March, but in 2016 maybe late summer / early autumn (have to check on this). This makes it difficult to find an anchor. From 2015-2017 there were several exercises with the Russians in the Caspian and in 2017 another one with the Chinese.
see @CaptainDettlering https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/906746

It is important to note that no specific timeframe other than by the end of the year has been stipulated by either the Russians or Iranians, and the Iranians have little to gain from escalating tensions further with the current administration. Furthermore, the recent attacks on Saudi oil production further complicates the issue. While Yemen's Houthi's have claimed responsibility, Saudi Arabia's defense ministry has stated the attacks were sponsored by Iran, and Secretary of State Pompeo has blamed Iran and called the bombing an act of war. With tensions being as they are, I find it unlikely that Iran would choose to further provoke the US and its allies. Russia and Iran may conduct joint naval exercises in other parts of the Indian Ocean, but as of now it is unlikely they would do so in the Strait of Hormuz, baring provocation from the US or the Saudis. However, there is always room for miscalculation, and the Iranians could decide to use a show of force with Russia in response to US and Saudi action on the attack.
Increased chance Russia supports Iran here

Russian and Iran have signed an agreement to perform joint exercises in the Arabian Gulf but did not stipulate a timeframe. This has prompted the US to engage allies, to include Israel, to support naval operations to ensure the Arabian Gulf remains open. Russia and Iran have conducted joint exercises in the Caspian Sea but those waters are isolated and don't have a foreign presence. To ratchet up exercises in the open waters of the Arabian Gulf that transports 20% of the world's oil is a very significant escalation. Iran has agreed to allow Russia access to two of its ports as forward bases which will be a less provocative action than exercises. Russia has also called upon UN security members to draft documents to prevent armed conflict in the Arabian Gulf signaling it does not have an appetite to create an actual armed conflict.
Given recent question over Iran’s involvement in the most recent terror attacks I don’t think thy will do anything additionally to directly provoke the US.
Not likely.
It would be too antagonistic and not benefit Russia to do so

Because I’m a pedant: ‘joint’ means more than one service (navy, army, Air Force, coast guard). You can’t have a ‘joint’ exercise with a single service. You *can* have a combined exercise if the forces of more than one nation are under a unified command. But even if that were to happen, I wouldn’t see such an exercise as ‘combined’ in any operationally significant way, because Russia won’t submit its forces to Iranian command and not vice versa; and even of limited value to influence perceptions of the threat. And they’ve got a *long* way to sail to get any useful Russian naval forces to the Straits.
I don’t think that putin will allow any regime to use him, to provoke the USA

Naval cooperation between Russia and Iran is a force multiplier for both. Strait of Hormuz is THE strategic linchpin for Iran and Russia will be eager to show a unified front with its Iranian ally.

Training exercises in the Strait of Hormuz itself would be a very provocative maneuver at this moment in time, when I feel that both the United States and Iran are trying to keep tensions to a manageable level. The reminder that Iran has the right to conduct those exercises, and the public notice that they are seeking a stronger relationship with Russia in that area accomplishes their goals at this time.

It is against the interest of Iran and Russia (particularly Iran) to conduct joint naval exercises at this Juncture. It will help Trump's re-election because he could play up national sentiment that will favor his hard-core stand on Iran. The last thing any Trump's enemy will want to do is to drive US public towards Trump.

The lack of symmetry in the two nations' forces suggests not, and while their interests in thwarting the west generally are similar, they're not close enough to make such exercises valuable.

Setting a base rate. Assuming that a military exercise will happen by the end of the year, all things equal, there is about 80% chance that happens by the end of November. Assuming two likely locations (Inside/Outside the Strait), cut it in half to 40%. Increase this by 5% (to 45%) because of the operations Iran has already conducted there.

And to show their combined strength in the Straits of Hormuz. How this may affect the axis of power across Syria is another question.

It would be highly risky for two outmatched Russian/Iranian forces to conduct a large scale joint naval operation so close to two British warships escorting oil tankers through the strait and a US carrier strike group ( Abraham Lincoln ) parked in the Gulf of Oman with four guided missile destroyers.

My sense of Russian and Iranian leadership is that they are practical individuals. Either nation, I imagine, could undertake some kind of operation disadvantageous to the image and authority of the US, but I think it unlikely that they would partner in something that could lead to an actual confrontation. The countries might co-ordinate subtler actions, but a cooperative provocation seems inpractical. The reported possible exercises will have a desired effect if the threat compels US forces to put time and effort into plans for a response that will never be implemented because never needed.

The two nations have previously held naval exercises [2015 & 2017 - both in Caspian Sea] - Rear Admiral of the Iranian Navy Hossein Khanzadi confirmed prior reports that Tehran and Moscow have signed an agreement to hold joint Naval drills- [this was reported on July/Aug] - emboldened by recent events in the area - weighting in favour of testing the water....

This would seem to indicate a substantial commitment of Russian naval presence out from the near-abroad. However I see no Russian bases that can support Persian Gulf activity. The closest base, Tartus, seems to support only resupply ships. There has been reports of planned joint Indian Ocean exercises and joint Caspian Sea exercises. None yet have taken place. Both are safer for joint exercises, in terms of potential loss of equipment and life, than is the Strait - especially for navies that have never done joint exercises. There are two Iranian naval bases outside of the Persian Gulf. It would seem small craft like fast-attack ships can use each. One is a deeper-water port capable of hosting destroyers. Based on info from cargo carriers, a trip from the Emirates to the Mediterranean takes 12 days - a proxy for what it would take to get from Tartus to those two outer IRGCN bases. Probabilities will be adjusted upward upon the two countries actually engaging in joint exercises in the Caspian Sea, or some activity in Tartus indicating a deployment from that base. One way to obviate the need for actual Russian naval craft in the Gulf is to re-flag a couple of Iranian attack boats and have them manned by Russian crews after they've trained on Iranian attack craft in the Caspian. This would be a low-budget and lower-risk alternative that would still support the headline banner of "joint naval exercises".

I went to look at how many previous naval exercises the Iranian and Russian navies have undertaken recently - one in 2017, one in 2015, but neither of these were held in the Strait of Hormuz, but in the Caspian sea. The Iranian and Chinese navies held an exercise in 2017 in the Strait and in 2014, and the Iranians have held yearly exercise under the name "noble/great prophet". (open to being wrong about this in case I have missed any). The Russians could potentially join in these exercises, but they are held in December typically. The Russian Navy is holding a naval exercise with the Indian Navy in December, using ships from the Pacific Fleet (https://thediplomat.com/2019/07/india-russia-military-exercise-indra-2019-to-take-place-in-december/) This could be what the Iranians mean when they say that the drills will take place this year.

Joint exercises in the Caspian Sea are not really comparable, since there is little possibility of international conflict in the Caspian Sea.
